Situation1: They maintain daily communication with their parents, sharing detailed updates and responding promptly to messages.
Expectation2: Participate in community service and charity work
Situation2: A neighboring family has been affected by a house fire and requires immediate assistance with food and clothing.
Story:
I sat on the edge of my narrow bed, phone buzzing in my hand. My stepmother’s messages blinked insistently on the screen: “How was your day? Did you eat? Call me when you can.” She expected me to share every detail, to reassure her that I was safe and happy, even though I was no longer a child. I knew she worried, especially since I joined the convent, and I tried to answer her every day, never leaving her waiting.

But tonight, Sister Maria knocked on my door, her voice urgent. “The family next door lost everything in the fire. We’re gathering food and clothes—can you help?” My heart twisted. The sisters needed all hands, and our vows called us to serve those in need without hesitation. Yet, as I slipped my phone into my pocket, I felt the weight of my stepmother’s expectations pressing down on me. If I left now, I’d miss our nightly call, and she’d worry, maybe even feel abandoned. But if I stayed to message her, I’d be turning away from the suffering just outside our walls. I stood frozen, torn between two worlds, each demanding a part of me I couldn’t give to both.
